hook.text: Seneca wrote an entire book on anger. He called it 'temporary madness.'

buildup.text: Anger feels justified in the moment. It promises power and justice but delivers regret.

discovery.text: Seneca's remedy: pause. The gap between stimulus and response is where wisdom lives.

twist.text: He didn't say never act on injustice. He said act from reason, not from rage. The result is better.

climax.text: Modern anger management techniques trace directly back to Seneca's two-thousand-year-old advice.

punchline.text: Anger punishes you for someone else's mistake.
